awd_titl_txt: The Institutional Foundations of Judicial Independence
awd_abstract_narration:
The state courts of last resort are significant final decisionmakers in many areas states govern, including family, many business disputes, and criminal law.  Second, it has long been a matter of common scholarly wisdom that courts do not tend to go against dominant political coalitions or major public policy initiatives of executives who are in power.  We have little understanding of the mechanisms, and whether judicial selection methods matter or whether public opinion seems to influence decisions.  We also have little systematic evidence over time about what these state courts of last resort do, or how decisions are influenced by public opinion or methods of judicial selection.  While some databases have been assembled, they have been coded by hand.  Advances in machine learning allow coding of cases for subject matter and date of a much larger number of cases than we currently have available.  The database of cases this project will generate will be useful to many scholars.

The development of web-scraping software tools for state court of last resort decisions is a significant innovation in the field, allowing coding of a much broader range of cases than have currently been available to scholars.  The plan to check machine coding with human coders will allow assessment of these new tools.  This project  will allow assessing change over time in courts and influences on judicial decisions in a way that relies on the most current methodologies regarding measuring public opinion and judicial decisions.

por.por_cntn:
Judicial independence is one of the most basic and controversial features of the American legal system; yet much remains unknown about whether and why judges tend to follow popular preferences and what factors influence the relationship between public opinion and judicial decision making. In this research project the investigators created a new database of every state supreme court decision from 1953 to 2014 by utilizing automated textual analysis programs to efficiently and inexpensively collect a wealth of critical information about these important institutions. This data facilitates the study how public opinion, state and national elected officials, and federal courts influence decision making in state courts of last resort, as well as how institutional structures mediate external influence on the judiciary. Our findings challenge prevailing wisdom in the field of judicial behavior and institutional design by suggesting that prior research has overstated the influence of institutional design in shaping judicial behavior. Specifically, our preliminary analyses indicate that changing judicial selection mechanisms within a state does not change the relationship between public opinion and judicial decision making. These findings have important implications for the nature of representative democracy, legal theory, and judicial politics, as well as practical implications for regarding judicial candidates, judicial policies, judicial reform, and the proper role of courts in society.
